questions.text: Identify the acid base disorder in a patient with the following values: pH- 7.2 and pCO2 – 80 mm Hg? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

As pH = 7.2 of the patient’s blood is lower than normal blood pH= 7.35-7.45, so, it’s a case of acidosis. As the acidosis is due to pCO2 = 80 mm of Hg that is higher than normal pCO2 = 35-45 mm of Hg, so, it’s a case of respiratory acidosis rather than metabolic acidosis which occurs due to decreased HCO3- ions.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Metabolic acidosis: This condition is characterized by a decrease in blood pH due to a primary reduction in bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. It is not associated with elevated pCO2 levels, which are seen in respiratory acidosis.

 

Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to a primary increase in bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. It is not consistent with the low pH and high pCO2 levels seen in the patient.

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to a primary decrease in pCO2 levels, often caused by hyperventilation. It is the opposite of the patient's condition, which shows low pH and high pCO2 levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Respiratory acidosis is indicated by a low blood pH and elevated pCO2 levels, suggesting impaired respiratory function and CO2 retention as the primary cause of the acidosis.

 

Ref: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-15

questions.text: Which of the following incisions is used for Appendicectomy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grid iron incision

 

The grid iron incision, also known as the McArthur incision, is the preferred surgical approach for an appendectomy. This incision is made at the McBurney point, which is located one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. The incision is muscle-splitting rather than cutting, which helps in minimizing muscle damage and promotes quicker recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kocher's incision: This is used for open cholecystectomy. It is a right subcostal incision, typically employed for gallbladder surgeries.

 

Option B. Morris incision: This is a flank incision used for accessing the retroperitoneal space, typically for renal surgeries.

 

Option D. Pfannensteil incision: This is a lower abdominal, transverse suprapubic incision often used for gynecological surgeries, such as cesarean sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The grid iron (McArthur) incision is the standard incision used for appendectomy, made at the McBurney point and characterized by a muscle-splitting approach.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis in a female with dysuria and vesicles for which she underwent an examination that revealed the presence of cells as shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

The image shown is a Tzanck smear, which is often used to diagnose infections caused by herpes viruses. The Tzanck smear reveals characteristic nuclear changes, including nuclear molding, margination of chromatin, and multinucleated giant cells, which are hallmark findings in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections.

 

Patients with HSV typically present with vesicular lesions on the genitalia accompanied by dysuria and pain. The infection involves the fusion of epithelial cells, leading to the appearance of multinucleated giant cells, a distinctive feature seen on Tzanck smears.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomoniasis: Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. It presents with frothy discharge and vaginal itching but does not produce vesicular lesions or the cytological features seen in HSV.

 

Option C. Human papilloma virus (HPV): HPV causes genital warts and is associated with cervical dysplasia and cancer. It does not produce vesicular lesions or characteristic changes like multinucleated giant cells seen in HSV.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections are characterized by large cells with prominent intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions, often described as "owl's eye" appearance. This differs from the nuclear molding and margination seen in HSV infections.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus infection is identified by multinucleated giant cells, nuclear molding, and margination on Tzanck smear, distinguishing it from other genital infections.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male came to the emergency after sustaining an injury and was given 0.25% bupivacaine for regional anesthesia. A few minutes later, he became unresponsive and pulseless. What would be the ideal management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CPR & 20% IV Intralipid

 

The scenario describes a case of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur after the administration of local anesthetics like bupivacaine. LAST can cause severe cardiovascular and central nervous system toxicity, leading to symptoms such as seizures, coma, and cardiovascular collapse, as seen in this patient.

 

The management of LAST involves:

 

  1. Immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) if the patient is unresponsive and pulseless.
  2. Administration of 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid). This treatment, known as lipid rescue or lipid emulsion therapy, acts by creating a "lipid sink" that absorbs the local anesthetic from the tissues and blood, reducing its toxic effects on the heart and brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPR & Calcium gluconate: Calcium gluconate is not the primary treatment for local anesthetic toxicity. It is used in cases of hyperkalemia or calcium channel blocker overdose.

 

Option C. CPR & Start Dobutamine infusion: While dobutamine can support cardiac function, it is not specific for treating local anesthetic toxicity and does not address the underlying cause.

 

Option D. CPR & Start NaHCO3 infusion: Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat metabolic acidosis and certain poisonings, such as tricyclic antidepressant overdose, but it is not specific for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), immediate management includes starting CPR and administering 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid) therapy. This approach helps to rapidly reduce the toxic effects of the local anesthetic on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. Upon examination, it is found that the patient is unable to pass urine and there is visible blood at the meatus. A retrograde urethrogram was performed as shown below. What is the most likely site of urethral injury? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Membranous urethra

 

  • Given the presentation of the patient - specifically the inability to pass urine, visible blood at the meatus after a motor vehicle accident and the RGU appearance - the membranous urethra is the most likely site of injury.
  • This is because it's closely associated with pelvic fractures, which are common in such accidents.
  • The management includes a retrograde urethrogram to confirm the injury, followed by the insertion of a suprapubic catheter to bypass the injured segment and allow for healing.
  • Membranous urethral rupture is typically associated with pelvic fractures and presents with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and a high-riding prostate on digital examination.
  • Bruising may also be visible over the pubic area, scrotum, and penis. Urine extravasates in the perivesical space.
  • The membranous urethra is the shortest and narrowest part of the male urethra and passes through the urogenital diaphragm.
  • This segment is particularly vulnerable in cases of pelvic fractures, often seen in motor vehicle accidents.
  • Clinical features, such as blood at the meatus and urinary retention as seen in the case, often point to an injury in this region.
  • On rectal examination, a high-riding prostate may be palpated, indicating disruption of the urethra below the prostate. This choice aligns with the given scenario and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulbar Urethra: It's a common site of injury due to straddle injuries (like falling onto a bicycle crossbar) because of its exposed location. It would typically result in a perineal hematoma.

 

Option B. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: This occurs due to a blow to the pelvis; however, no blood is seen at the urethral meatus.

 

Option D. Penile Urethra: This portion is within the shaft of the penis, encased within the corpus spongiosum. Trauma to the penile urethra usually results from direct trauma to the penis, such as in the context of a penile fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Membranous urethral injuries are common in pelvic fractures, presenting with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and possibly a high-riding prostate on rectal examination. Retrograde urethrogram is used for confirmation.

questions.text: A soft friable extradural hematoma with a honeycomb appearance on autopsy is seen in: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Heat hematoma

 

Explanation:

 

Heat hematoma (also called burn hematoma) shows characteristic features that distinguish it from traumatic extradural hematoma. The defining features include a honeycomb appearance and friable consistency, which are the key diagnostic features. Heat hematoma is recognized as one of the artifacts found in bodies exposed to extreme heat.

 

Comparison with Traumatic EDH

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coagulopathy - While coagulopathy can affect clot formation, it doesn't produce the characteristic honeycomb appearance mentioned in the question. Coagulopathy-related bleeding typically lacks the specific pattern described.

 

Option C. Postmortem; blunt force - Postmortem blunt force wouldn't produce the described honeycomb appearance. Postmortem injuries show no vital reaction, and the blood doesn't typically form organized patterns.

 

Option D. Antemortem; blunt force - Traumatic extradural hematomas due to blunt force have a smooth, jelly-like appearance rather than the honeycomb, friable consistency described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heat hematoma (EDH due to heat) has distinctive characteristics including honeycomb appearance, friable consistency, bilateral presentation, and ability to cross suture lines—all opposite to traumatic EDH features.

choices.text: Cold water induces nystagmus to same side
Directional preponderance occurs towards the side of Central lesion

questions.text: All of the following are true about Fitzgerald-Hallpike test, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cold water induces nystagmus to same side

 

Explanation:

 

The Fitzgerald-Hallpike test (bithermal caloric test) uses water at temperatures above and below body temperature to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal and induce nystagmus. Cold water irrigation induces nystagmus to the opposite side, not the same side. This follows the mnemonic "COWS" (Cold-Opposite, Warm-Same), which indicates that cold water induces nystagmus to the opposite side while warm water induces nystagmus to the same side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bithermal Caloric Test: This is a correct statement. Fitzgerald-Hallpike test is indeed also known as the bithermal caloric test. It uses water at 30°C (cold) and 44°C (warm) to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canals.

 

Option C. Directional preponderance occurs towards the side of Central lesion: This is a correct statement. Directional preponderance (where nystagmus is stronger in one direction than the other) typically occurs toward the side of a central lesion, and away from the side in a peripheral lesion.

 

Option D. All are true: This option is incorrect because statement B is false. Cold water causes nystagmus to the opposite side, not the same side.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In the Fitzgerald-Hallpike caloric test, cold water irrigation causes nystagmus to the opposite side, following the mnemonic "COWS" (Cold-Opposite, Warm-Same), which is a fundamental principle in vestibular testing and helps differentiate various vestibular disorders.

questions.text: What is the distance from the upper incisor teeth to the bronchial constriction of the esophagus? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C. 27 cm

 

Explanation:

 

The bronchial constriction of the esophagus occurs at the level where the left main bronchus crosses the esophagus, which is approximately 27 cm (11 inches) from the upper incisor teeth. This constriction is located at the T6 vertebral level. The esophagus has four sites of constriction: the cervical constriction at the cricopharyngeal junction (C6), the aortic constriction where the aortic arch crosses (T4), the bronchial constriction at the left main bronchus (T6), and the diaphragmatic constriction at the esophageal hiatus (T10). These constrictions are important to consider during endoscopic procedures or when evaluating patients with dysphagia.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 15 cm - Incorrect. This distance corresponds to the cervical constriction at the cricopharyngeal junction.

 

Option B. 22 cm - Incorrect. This distance corresponds to the aortic constriction where the aortic arch crosses the esophagus.

 

Option D. 40 cm - Incorrect. This distance corresponds to the diaphragmatic constriction at the esophageal hiatus.

 

Educational objective:

 

The bronchial constriction of the esophagus lies 27 cm (11 inches) from the upper incisor teeth, at the level where the left main bronchus crosses the esophagus (T6 vertebral level).

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is found to be associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bitot’s spots

 

Vitamin A deficiency is a significant public health issue, especially in developing countries, and it is associated with various ocular manifestations collectively known as xerophthalmia. One of the most specific and classic signs of Vitamin A deficiency is the presence of Bitot’s spots. These are foamy, whitish accumulations on the conjunctiva, typically located on the temporal side of the eye. They are caused by the buildup of keratin due to the lack of Vitamin A, which is essential for maintaining the health of the conjunctiva and cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: This is a common, benign, yellowish growth on the conjunctiva that is unrelated to Vitamin A deficiency. It is associated with aging and UV exposure.

 

Option C. Pterygium: This is a growth of fleshy tissue that may extend onto the cornea. It is linked to UV exposure and chronic irritation but is not associated with Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option D. Stocker's line: This is an iron deposit line seen at the leading edge of a pterygium and is not related to Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WHO Classification of Xerophthalmia

questions.text: Acrodynia is primarily associated with poisoning by which substance? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Mercury

 

Explanation:

 

Acrodynia (Pink disease) is distinctly associated with mercury poisoning. It is seen mostly in children due to idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction to repeated ingestion or contact with mercury. This condition presents with characteristic signs including pinkish morbilliform acral rashes, desquamation of palms and soles, pain in the extremities, flushing, itching, swelling, tachycardia, hypertension, excessive salivation or perspiration, weakness, irritability, photophobia, anorexia, insomnia, and constipation or diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenolic acid - Phenolic acid is not associated with acrodynia. Phenolic compounds like carbolic acid (phenol) cause different toxicity patterns including local corrosive effects and systemic manifestations like carboluria.

 

Option C. Oxalic acid - Oxalic acid poisoning primarily causes hypocalcemic symptoms including tetany due to calcium oxalate formation. Acrodynia is not a feature of oxalic acid poisoning.

 

Option D. Carbolic acid (phenol) - While carbolic acid causes various toxic effects including local anesthesia, eschar formation, and carboluria (dark green urine), it is not associated with acrodynia. Chronic carbolic acid poisoning leads to phenolic marasmus (weight loss, anorexia).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acrodynia (Pink disease) is a distinctive syndrome associated with mercury toxicity in children, characterized by pink rashes, pain in extremities, and autonomic dysfunction.

questions.text: Epithelial mesenchymal transcription is mediated by which transcription factors? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SNAIL/TWIST

 

Epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a crucial process in cancer metastasis where epithelial cells lose their cell-cell adhesion and gain migratory properties. This process is primarily mediated by SNAIL and TWIST transcription factors. These factors cause:

 

  • Decreased expression of E-cadherin (epithelial marker)
  • Increased expression of mesenchymal markers like vimentin and smooth muscle actin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cathepsin D

 

  • This is incorrect as cathepsin D is a protease involved in protein degradation
  • While it may play a role in tissue invasion, it's not a transcription factor mediating EMT

 

Option C. MMP-9 (Matrix Metalloprotease-9)

 

  • This is incorrect as MMP-9 is an enzyme involved in degrading extracellular matrix
  • It's important for invasion but doesn't mediate EMT transcription

 

Option D. TTF-1 (Thyroid Transcription Factor-1)

 

  • This is incorrect as TTF-1 is a transcription factor specific to thyroid and lung tissue development
  • It's not involved in EMT

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SNAIL and TWIST are the key transcription factors responsible for mediating epithelial-mesenchymal transition, a crucial step in cancer metastasis.

questions.text: From which structure does the female urethra develop? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Urogenital sinus

 

Explanation:

 

The female urethra develops from the urogenital sinus. During embryonic development, the cloaca divides into a posterior anorectal canal and an anterior urogenital sinus. The urogenital sinus further differentiates into three parts: the upper part forms the urinary bladder, the middle part forms the female urethra, and the lower part contributes to the vestibule of the vagina. The female urethra is therefore a direct derivative of the urogenital sinus and is lined by endoderm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mesonephric duct - This is incorrect because the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct) regresses in females. In males, it develops into the epididymis, vas deferens, ejaculatory duct, and seminal vesicle. The mesonephric duct does not contribute to the female urethra.

 

Option C. Ureteric bud - This is incorrect because the ureteric bud is an outgrowth from the mesonephric duct that induces the development of the metanephric blastema. It forms the collecting system of the kidney including the collecting tubules, calyces, renal pelvis, and ureter, but not the urethra.

 

Option D. Metanephric blastema - This is incorrect because the metanephric blastema is a condensation of intermediate mesoderm that forms the secretory portion of the nephron (glomerulus, proximal and distal tubules, loop of Henle). It forms the functional tissue of the kidney but does not contribute to the urethra.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The female urethra develops from the middle portion of the urogenital sinus, which is an endoderm-lined structure formed by the division of the cloaca. This developmental path explains why the female urethral lining is continuous with the bladder epithelium.

questions.text: Which extracellular cell adhesion is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occludens

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae disrupts occludens, specifically targeting tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, which impairs their barrier function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrin: Primarily involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion, not typically disrupted by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option B. Cadherin: Important for cell-cell adhesion in adherens junctions, not the main target of Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as occludens are indeed affected by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio cholerae specifically targets occludens, which are crucial components of tight junctions, thereby compromising intestinal epithelial barrier functions.

choices.text: Non vigorous baby
Rh negative mother

questions.text: When should early cord clamping be done? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Non vigorous baby

 

Early cord clamping should be done primarily when the baby is non-vigorous/ hypoxic baby i.e. not breathing, or not crying at birth. Immediate neonatal resuscitation is required in such cases to address the baby's urgent need for oxygen and support.

 

Delaying cord clamping in a non-vigorous baby could waste crucial time needed for resuscitation efforts. According to WHO guidelines, the only absolute contraindication to delayed cord clamping is a non-vigorous baby.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rh negative mother: Although older guidelines suggested early cord clamping in Rh-negative mothers to reduce the risk of fetomaternal hemorrhage, current guidelines do not strongly recommend this practice. The benefits of delayed cord clamping, such as reducing anemia in the baby, outweigh the potential risks.

 

Option C. Preterm: For preterm babies, delayed cord clamping is recommended to help prevent anemia and improve blood volume. Preterm infants benefit significantly from the additional blood received during delayed clamping.

 

Option D. Pre-eclampsia: Pre-eclampsia is not a contraindication for delayed cord clamping. Delayed clamping can still provide the newborn with additional blood and help prevent anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early cord clamping is indicated for non-vigorous babies who require immediate resuscitation efforts.

questions.text: A dwarf female patient brought to the hospital with a history of primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely placed nipples. What is the most common karyotype associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45X0

 

Explanation

 

The presentation of a dwarf female patient with primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely spaced nipples is characteristic of Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, most commonly represented by the karyotype 45X0. This syndrome is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Turner syndrome, characterized by the karyotype 45X0, is the most common chromosomal disorder associated with features such as primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely spaced nipples in females.

questions.text: What is the most common anatomical site for a congenital diaphragmatic hernia? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterolateral


The most common site for congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the posterolateral aspect of the diaphragm, specifically on the left side. This type of hernia is known as the Bochdalek hernia, which occurs due to a failure of the pleuroperitoneal membrane to close properly during fetal development. This defect typically occurs on the left side because the liver provides a protective barrier on the right, making right-sided defects less common. Bochdalek hernias account for the majority of congenital diaphragmatic hernias.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterolateral: This location is associated with Morgagni hernia, which is less common and usually occurs on the right side near the sternum. It does not typically involve the posterolateral region, making it a less frequent site for congenital diaphragmatic hernias.

 

Option B. Central tendon: The central tendon of the diaphragm does not commonly present with congenital hernias, as it is primarily a strong fibrous part of the diaphragm, less prone to defects.

 

Option C. Crural: Crural defects are not commonly associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernias. These defects would more likely involve esophageal hernias rather than congenital diaphragmatic hernias.

 

Educational Objective:


The most common site for congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the posterolateral region, predominantly on the left side, known as the Bochdalek hernia.

questions.text: A healthcare professional nurse was ordered by a doctor to take patient’s blood sample for glucose estimation. She took this patient’s sample at 8 a.m. which of the following is used to inhibit glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium fluoride


When a blood sample is taken for glucose estimation, it’s important to prevent glycolysis (the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells and leukocytes after collection), because glycolysis would artificially lower the measured glucose level.
 

Sodium fluoride is the most commonly used glycolysis inhibitor in blood collection tubes for glucose testing.
 

Mechanism: It inhibits the enzyme enolase in the glycolysis pathway, effectively halting glucose breakdown.
 

Often combined with potassium oxalate (an anticoagulant) in a gray-top tube for glucose measurement.

 

Other options:


Option A. Sodium citrate – Anticoagulant used mainly for coagulation studies (e.g., PT, aPTT). It works by binding calcium, not by inhibiting glycolysis.
 

Option B. Potassium oxalate – Anticoagulant that binds calcium, but does not stop glycolysis on its own. It’s used in combination with sodium fluoride in gray-top tubes.
 

Option D. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) – Anticoagulant used for hematology tests (CBC, ESR). It binds calcium but doesn’t prevent glycolysis.
 

Educational Objective:

 

 

When a blood sample is taken for glucose estimation, it’s important to prevent glycolysis (the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells and leukocytes after collection), because glycolysis would artificially lower the measured glucose level.

questions.text: Reinke crystals are seen in which of the following gonadal tumours: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leydig cell tumor

 

  • Reinke crystals are a specific and distinguishing feature of Leydig cell tumors. These crystals are eosinophilic, rod-shaped, crystalline inclusions found in the cytoplasm of Leydig cells. Leydig cell tumors are non-germ cell, sex cord-stromal tumors of the testicles that are typically benign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seminoma: Does not feature Reinke crystals; characterized by uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei, often associated with lymphocytic infiltration.

 

Option B. Yolk sac Tumor: Lacks Reinke crystals; known for Schiller-Duval bodies and a pattern resembling endodermal sinus structures.

 

Option D. Sertoli cell Tumor: Also does not contain Reinke crystals; these tumors may show tubular or trabecular growth patterns and are often clinically silent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke crystals are pathognomonic of Leydig cell tumors of the testis and are useful in differentiating these from other testicular neoplasms.

questions.text: Which glands can be involved in Bromhidrosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both Apocrine and Eccrine Glands

 

  • Bromhidrosis refers to offensive body odor originating from apocrine and eccrine sweat glands.
  • Specifically, bromhidrosis affects "Apocrine (Axilla) or Eccrine (Feet)" glands. 
  • While apocrine glands produce odorous secretions containing pheromones associated with body odor (particularly in axillary regions), eccrine glands can also be affected, especially on the feet. 
  • The interaction between sweat and bacteria on the skin surface leads to the breakdown of sweat components, resulting in malodorous compounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apocrine Sweat Glands only: 

 

  • While apocrine glands are commonly associated with body odor due to their secretions containing pheromones, bromhidrosis isn't limited to these glands alone. 
  • This would be correct if bromhidrosis only affected the axillary region.

 

Option B. Eccrine Sweat Glands only: 

 

  • Eccrine glands can cause bromhidrosis, particularly on the feet, but this option is incomplete since apocrine glands are also involved. 
  • This would be correct if bromhidrosis only affected the feet.

 

Option C. Sebaceous Glands: 

 

  • Sebaceous glands produce sebum through holocrine secretion and function to lubricate skin and hair. 
  • They aren't primarily responsible for bromhidrosis. 
  • These glands are associated with conditions like acne vulgaris rather than body odor.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Bromhidrosis (offensive body odor) can originate from both apocrine glands (primarily in axillary regions) and eccrine glands (commonly on feet), resulting from bacterial decomposition of sweat components on the skin surface.

questions.text: Match the following (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4, E-5

 

The correct matching of the items is as follows:

 

  • Eonism (Transvestism): Wearing clothes of the opposite sex, often for sexual gratification or due to gender identity disorder.
  • Frotteurism: The act of rubbing one's genitals against another person, usually in a crowded place.
  • Necrophilia: Engaging in sexual activity with dead bodies.
  • Exhibitionism: The act of exposing one's genitalia to unsuspecting individuals.
  • Passive Algoglenia: Deriving sexual gratification from experiencing pain, also known as masochism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eonism (Transvestism) is wearing clothes of the opposite sex, Frotteurism is rubbing genitals against another person, Necrophilia is having sex with dead bodies, Exhibitionism is exposing genitalia to unsuspecting individuals, and Passive Algoglenia is gratification from experiencing pain.

questions.text: Most potent biological Estrogen: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Estradiol

 

Explanation:

 

Estrogens are a group of steroid hormones that play a crucial role in the regulation of the female reproductive system and secondary sexual characteristics. Among the different forms of estrogen, estradiol (E2) is the most potent and biologically active. Estradiol is primarily produced by the ovaries and is the dominant form of estrogen during the reproductive years.

 

Estradiol binds with the highest affinity to estrogen receptors compared to other forms like estrone and estriol, which is why it exerts the most potent biological effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estrone: Estrone (E1) is less potent than estradiol and is the primary form of estrogen after menopause. It has a weaker affinity for estrogen receptors and thus, exerts less biological activity.

 

Option C. Estriol: Estriol (E3) is the weakest of the three primary estrogens. It is primarily produced during pregnancy and has the least biological activity due to its low affinity for estrogen receptors.

 

Option D. Conjugated estrogen: Conjugated estrogens are a mixture of several types of estrogens, typically used in hormone replacement therapy. They are not as biologically potent as estradiol when considered individually.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is the most potent biological estrogen.

choices.text: Reduce the swelling and do the observation
Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about a patient who presented in the OPD with a swelling as shown in the image? The swelling is reducible. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

 

The image shows a reducible swelling on the patient's back, which strongly suggests a hernia. Hernias are defined as protrusions of an organ or tissue through an abnormal opening. When a hernia is reducible, it means that the protruded organ or tissue can be pushed back into its original place.

 

The standard treatment for a reducible hernia is surgical repair. This often involves reducing the hernia and reinforcing the weakened area with a mesh to prevent recurrence. This approach is particularly important to avoid complications such as strangulation or incarceration of the herniated contents, which can become medical emergencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and drainage: This procedure is typically used for abscesses or other collections of pus, not for hernias. Hernias do not require drainage as there is no infection involved.

 

Option B. Reduce the swelling and do the observation: While reducing the swelling might temporarily alleviate symptoms, observation alone is not a definitive treatment for a hernia. Without surgical repair, the hernia is likely to recur and may lead to complications.

 

Option D. Observation alone: This option is not advisable for hernias as it does not address the underlying defect in the abdominal wall or the risk of potential complications. Hernias generally require surgical intervention to prevent recurrence and complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For reducible hernias, the appropriate treatment is surgical repair with mesh reinforcement to prevent recurrence and avoid complications. Observation alone is not sufficient, and procedures such as incision and drainage are not applicable.

questions.text: A child presents with erythematous scaly patches in the perioral region, mucosal ulcers, and impaired epithelial wound healing. What is the likely mineral deficiency associated with this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc deficiency

 

The clinical features of periorificial dermatitis and stomatitis in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, seen in zinc deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency - Most common micronutrient deficiency globally. It presents with iron-deficiency anemia. It presents clinically with pallor, fatigue, weakness, shortness of breath, light-headedness.

 

Option C. Calcium deficiency - Leads to rickets in children. Apart from clinical vignette of rickets there can be Muscle cramps and stiffness, Tingling and Numbness, Tetany.

 

Option D. Copper deficiency - Leads to anemia, growth retardation, defective keratinization and pigmentation of hair, hypothermia, degenerative changes in aortic elastin, osteopenia, and neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency disorder- Acrodermatitis enteropathica

questions.text: What will be the duration of below-knee POP cast applied for the following injury?(NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6-8 weeks

 

For injuries like the one shown in the X-ray (fracture at the base of the fifth metatarsal), the typical treatment involves immobilization using a plaster of Paris (POP) cast. Foot injuries, including fractures of the metatarsal bones, usually require a period of 6-8 weeks to allow for proper healing. This timeframe is standard for most metatarsal fractures, ensuring that the bone has adequate time to heal and regain strength. Specifically, fractures like the Jones fracture (involving the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction) or the Pseudojones fracture (avulsion fracture) are commonly immobilized for this duration.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fractures of the metatarsals, including those at the base of the fifth metatarsal, are typically treated with a below-knee plaster cast for a duration of 6-8 weeks to ensure proper healing.

questions.text: MEN 1 syndrome is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid adenoma

 

Explanation

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, also known as Wermer's syndrome, is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the MEN1 gene. It is characterized by tumors in three primary endocrine glands, known as the "three Ps":

 

  1. Parathyroid adenoma: Leading to primary hyperparathyroidism.
  2. Pituitary adenoma: Most commonly prolactinomas.
  3. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors: Which can include gastrinomas, insulinomas, and non-functioning pancreatic tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parotid tumor and Option C. Renal cell carcinoma: Not associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option D. Pheochromocytoma: Associated with MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndromes, but not MEN 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEN 1 syndrome, also known as Wermer's syndrome, is associated with tumors in the parathyroid glands, pituitary gland, and pancreatic islet cells, with parathyroid adenoma being a common manifestation.
